text:
PROFESSOR: Another
major way that students

can receive feedback is
what I call the review. When they have done at least
half of the amount of work,

we call it, sometimes,
a mid-term review. And we come together
and invite a number

of critics who are either people
teaching at the school or often

outside practitioners to come
in and to discuss the project.

Now the old-time review was what
we called a jury system where

the student presented their
work to half a dozen critics, and the critics
then made comments.

But I don't consider
that very educational because the student
became defensive, and, frankly, the
jury members became

offensive in their
criticism sometimes. Instead this system
that I do at the review

is called the one on one
where one faculty member sits with a student for
a period of 45 minutes,

discuss the project, helps
the students see things they hadn't seen,
and then moves on

and another faculty member
comes and talks again. And during the
afternoon a student

will often see three or four
different faculty members and can get three or four
different points of view

because in architecture there
are no rights and wrongs. There are different
ideas about it.

And the job of the
student, which I tell them, is to edit and take those
things from the review that

are useful for their
project and perhaps not take everything that is given.

So what you're about to
see is a typical review of which about 14 outside
people have been invited,

practitioners, architects,
engineers, and faculty.

During the afternoon,
there will be

these continuous one-on-one
discussions taking place. And then, finally,
at the end, you'll see a summing up or a
summary of where we are

and where we're going
to the next step. So this is a mid-term review.

The intention of this
course is several.

But one is making
architecture for people--

does anybody have a-- [INAUDIBLE] always has a laser
pointer, do you have one? - Yeah, I got it. PROFESSOR: In fact,
I think you've

given me about a dozen
so far that I lose, so. - That's OK. [INAUDIBLE]

PROFESSOR: And I think it's the
responsibility of architects of making places that are not
only beautiful, but that--

oh, this is a better one. Not only beautiful, as
these Chinese water gardens, but a place where groups can
be, one person can be, lovers
can be. You can take your photographs. It is a place of celebration.

That's our responsibility,
that's our job as architects. So that's part of the course
is making places that have all

these different definitions.  The other part of our
course is this notion

of nature and architecture,
which I'll talk more about. But I find here that this
is all built, of course.

But it doesn't matter. It's either nature or it's
all built. It's all one thing. So in fact, this notion
of building in nature.

I have problems with. I think building and
nature is the same. Ones growing, and
it takes longer.

The other one is faster. So I want to get
rid of that notion. Next.

And it's about the place in
between the sky and the water or the sky and the land.

Therefore, sky
form and land form, that's the place where
architecture takes place.

Now, here's some of
this nature or not. This is Block
Island, Hay Barrel--

Hay Bale. I don't if this is
nature or architecture. I love it, but it
doesn't matter.

But it's one of the two. This is Italy where this
is, of course, architecture. But the nature makes
it fuzzy, which it is.

So it's that
combination of the two. Next.

There are times when-- my definition of
good architecture is that if the building is
not there, it would be better.

Well, this is Block Island,
the famous lighthouse. And somehow, for me, this and
this fit as does the village.
This is taken from my house. Block Island fits with the land. That's the objective.

If you can't make it so
it fits into landscape and looks better,
go home because you

don't want to muck it up
because we're mucking up the world at a great rate. Next.

Here are some folks who did
not muck up the world at all. In fact, produced some
great things of beauty.

This is in Canyon de Chelly
where the Native Americans

built in here. Ah, there it is. And here. And the famous White
House, which is in here.

And it's difficult to
know which is built and which isn't,
but it's so obvious. This is a path in
Canyon de Chelly

that's been worn by feet. This is, obviously, a piece of
granite put in the landscape

on Block Island, same thing. Next. And then, of course,
it's about building

the ordinary and
the extraordinary, which we get into more. Here's an ordinary
Greek village, your common Greek
village and not so

common boat, which
is out of scale. But nevertheless, this is all
built. You go around the corner

and you find this quite
extraordinary piece of architecture, which is the
same system of construction

as this. Next. Now the first problem - there's
two problems here today,

and they're going to be
another one after this. We're just getting
warmed up, by the way -
was building in the landscape. And these are some examples. Fay Jones of one example. Gaudi, that tries to imitate.

Next The master of the
horizontal, Frank Lloyd Wright,

which relates to the land
better than anyone I know. And Piano, who relates to the
sky better than anyone I know.

Next. The vertical and the horizontal. The notion of transitions
from the inside to the outside

that-- we are not talking about
Philip Johnson architecture where the glass bangs
against the wall-- or the ground.

But we're talking about
transitions from the inside to the outside. Next.

The first problem,
which you will see here in some different form -
the quarry got disassembled

and has been trying
to be reassembled, and not quite there yet at
all; but it's getting there

- is a beautiful quarry
in Rockport, which has been filled with water.

It's probably one of the
most beautiful pieces of architecture
I've seen around, and I didn't know it was
here for many, many years.

Next. This, of course, was all
quarried and then abandoned

and then nature took
over and eroded. And the first
problem was that they had to build a place for our
classroom for me and them

somewhere on the quarry,
which you will see examples of such as this one here.

And it couldn't exceed,
I think, 750 square feet. Next, more pictures of this
great quarry, next, that we all

thought we ought to move up to. There's some great
architecture just sitting there made, but also--
is it nature? Is it built? I don't know. Next.

And now the second
problem is another quarry, which is what we're going
to discuss primarily today.

But both are here,
both problems are here. This is like a mid-term
review, but the emphasis

is on the second. Is that we are looking
at the north end,

and we're thinking of
it as a quarry just as the other quarry. In this quarry, people live.

But still, it's like a quarry,
the canyons, the cliffs.

And we've taken an area
that you see about-- it's a little larger than that. Well, here it is on the
model, this partial.

And we are building on
the sides of buildings

like this one you'll find-- like this one actually
on the other side.

Or-- is that the church? Or on the rooftops--
no, here's the church.

Here's a site. Something's wrong here. This is confusing me. But anyways-- it's
turned around, I think.

We're building on
the tops of buildings or on the sides of
buildings or even lapping

over the tops and the sides. It's a place for the studio
projecting their life

10 years from now, who
they'll be, what they'll do, how many children we have.

This studio has got
quite a few children. I think we've
probably got a dozen. Felix has got six or seven. Where's Felix?

How many are you up to? You got five, at
least, kids in yours, and some I think Sarah gave
you a couple of kids also--
[LAUGHTER]  --because Sara ran out of room. Is that right, you--

But last year, we only had one-- we had a similar problem, and
we only had one kid, I think, in the whole place.

They are not intending to
work here except for computer because the next problem
I'll show you in a second

is going to be a community space
where it will be a work center. So this is a live center on
the rooftops of the quarry.

Next. And so this is the
kind of architecture that's already there,
and, of course,

people are already doing
this in different ways. There somebody got more
space right next to our site.

Next. So what we did is
that we found 13

sites, 13 people in this class,
and we designated areas in red.

And then we had a lottery,
and they got their site. I think there may have been some
arguing going on or fighting

of changing of sites. But everybody got a
problem, so to speak because every site had some kind
of a social problem with it.

Just to show you
where we're going. From here, starting
after the vacation, is that-- this
again, is our area.

And when I showed you--
you'll see on this are all the rooftops along
the way or sides of buildings.

And then this piece is a
somewhat vacant piece of land of which we are going to build
a community space for them who

are living in the sky, as
well as the north enders, as well as for the tourists.

And finally, bring nature
back to the site, to the city. So we make a complete circle.

We start with the quarry. We go to the quarry that's
built, then we come back to it.

Next. And I think there's a
couple of slides of that. So that's what they're going
to work on starting next week.
[VIDEO PLAYBACK] - Last time, I mean, I had--

I have the two layers of grid-- - Yeah. - --but then I could pretty much
push the boxes out as much as I

wanted to. - Mm-hmm. - So this time I restricted
myself to five different zones
from the side. You can see like-- - One, two. - So--

- [INAUDIBLE] - --that would be more-- - Oh, the-- instead of
grade at two planes--

- Yeah. - --you've got things all
over at 5 different points-- - Yeah. - --five different
distances from the base.

- Right. - [INAUDIBLE] - It's basically like having
five sets of stairs coming out.

They're at three-feet intervals. So one set of stairs
would be at zone one. And [INAUDIBLE] Just
a regular thing--

- Is the stairs-- are the stairs a
large part of what-- - What's go-- yeah. - Yeah. - --for that? - Yeah. Yes.

- OK. - Well-- - And most importantly,
you put in the stairs. - Pardon? - You put in the stairs. - Yes, mm-hmm, the stairs.

- That looks like
a neat compromise. - What did we talk
about last time? - We said they could be
in little glass tubes--

- Oh, glass tubes. - They could be in
glass boxes [INAUDIBLE].. We can put the whole
thing in a glass box. - Right. Right. - Those are some of the
things we threw out there.

- I mean, with having
stairs outside, I mean, I was afraid
of the diagonal

taking over the whole thing. So that's why I
used glass plus I put these square rectangular
things in between them

just to break it down and
add more layering, I guess. - Well, between-- I'm sorry. Between--

- Between-- - Got it. - --or here. - Yeah, so the walls are
limited to the space needed

by the stairs. They continue so that they fall
within a rectilinear box right. - Right. - And the language of the
box itself has changed a lot.

- Yes. Basically, the window--
the window arrangement--

the slit just didn't
give enough light. And the way that I
had the boxes here

just made this make more sense
because I was cutting things down and then-- - Yeah.

- --making them more. - This seems like a compromise
between what you had and what Jan suggested. - Mm-hmm. - It seems like he was
pushing for multiple finishes

and materials on each box. We can talk about
a million things. One of them is structure. And yeah, frankly, you
shot yourself in the foot

or stole a lot of the strength
that you had in the changes you made to the grid.

Did you do it
because you thought you needed to structure
for the stairs

or do the stairs drive
the different bars more conceptually?

- Sorry. You mean did I place the
columns and the beams

as a result of where
I wanted to come? - Yeah. - No. There was-- - You just did it to--

- It was more of supporting
the boxes than the stairs because I thought the stairs-- - Except you're not, and
we used to do it better.

- Oh, really? - Well, maybe you are. - A little bit. - You started by saying
you're-- structurally,

you're in trouble. Now you're changing your tune. - Well, I'm saying
it would support it a little, but
definitely not enough.

- I guess the one that
worries me the most is the high brown one. - Mm-hmm, that one
just sticks out there. - And if you just
dropped in a vertical--
- Uh-huh. - --or two-- - Right. - I'd feel a lot better.

At the corners
farthest from the wall - Farthest from the wall? Oh-- - It doesn't have to be right
on the corner, but close enough.
Right now you've got--

yeah, in elevation,
you're asking a lot. You've got a wall.

You got the box. And basically, they're
held up like that. - Mm-hmm. - If you could give me--

I'm not-- and
that'd be one thing, if you gave me a column there. But it could be there. It could be here.

- Mm-hmm. - Somewhere more than halfway
out, so it's a decent canopy. And if you gave me a plan--
if they were--

I'd love to have two. They don't have to line
up with each other.

One could be further
back than the other. There's a column, column,
we'd be in better shape.

There are a lot of
wall-based things here that don't touch the ground. Hers doesn't touch
the ground at all-- - Right. - --and I think that's correct.

Yours has almost grown
out of the ground. I mean, I don't mind
the fact that yours is on stilts touching the ground.

And I wouldn't design
around to get rid of it. I will say this though. They use some kind of lateral
stiffening or diagonal bracing

or something to hold you rigid
is going to be necessary. You can imagine a field of just
perfectly rectilinear members

and joints, be they vertical
or horizontal or whatsoever. If there's nobody in
there to brace you

and those are all
hinge connections, it'll all flop around would be
another way to think about it. Have you had any
structures courses yet?

- Yeah - If you took-- looks like a soccer goal
with hinge connections

all the way around. - Mm-hmm. - That's not stable, and
it can flop right over.

Three ways to fix it are,
number one, moment connections where you go in and change
the way the thing is detail

and make each of
those connections able to withstand
that lateral twist. - Mm-hmm. - Does that makes sense? - Mm-hmm.

- Step two is [INAUDIBLE] where
you go in and fill it with cinder blocks.

- OK. - And now it's not
going to fall over. It's less effective
as a soccer goal.

The third would be to brace
it, to put in cables somewhere. - Right. - And that's where he's headed.

I think it'd be a
shame because it's such a poem right now of a
clear, limited, beautiful set

of elements. And I think introducing that,
A, would clutter it and detract

from its beauty. And B, it would really
change it in a way it doesn't have to happen.
We could get away without it. How could we do it?

Number one, we could
add some of those guys. - Moment-- - Some bracing.

- OK. - Instead of putting
it in the framework and hanging these boxes from it,
you could put it in the boxes.

- OK, like in the walls? - Let's say that you've
got column, column, beam
coming out, beam coming out.

Imagine-- conceptually,
the frames are there first. We come in and we build a
box on it, on that frame.

And there's our box. And within that wall
around the windows, it can easily be done
around the windows.

We put in members in that
skin, and then we cover it up.

And there are the
windows, and the finish has whatever we want on it. Instead of the boxes
purely being cargo--

- Mm-hmm. - Instead of saying grid is
structure, boxes are cargo.

We can make the boxes
work for us structurally, and they can lend rigidity
to the whole thing. Does that make sense?

- Mm-hmm.  - You could also do it just
by the way the joints are

put together, things like that. You don't-- and
here's option number-- so option one is do
it with the boxes.

Option two is do
it with the joints. OK, what that just
means is instead of--

imagine these are
tubular steel forms.

Maybe that's what you
want, maybe it's not. But we've got two boxes
coming together made of steel.

Conceptually, the
hinge connection may just be welded
around the outside.

So making the moment
connection, it may just mean that
there's an angle on it. And the same thing
on the bottom.

And the weld is
different, more longer. - Mm-hmm.

- It seems like a simple change. Conceptually, in
the way it works, it's a very different change. We can do it without
adding all this stuff.
- And by having those-- sorry. By having those--

- Go ahead. - --structures in there you
don't have to worry about where you place your windows because-- - It's not that-- you don't
have to worry about where

you're placing windows. But, with maybe an
exception or two, you could always
find a way to make

it work without
screwing up the windows that you want to put in. - OK. - For example, I
did a big building

where we had to put
in some of these. Brace frames is typically
what you call them. You get a whole
building like that. You're structural
engineer will say then,

it's all going to fall over
unless they have a brace frame somewhere. So let me do that, and let you
do that, and let me do that.

That's what they'll tell you. We had a building where that's
exactly what he told me. I said, well, jeez,
that's the stairway,

and I need to put
the door there. - Mm-hmm. - He said, OK, I'll
do that instead. And you can do the same thing
to work around your windows.

- OK. - Option number three is
do it with the stairs.

In general, bracing is all
about putting in diagonals

because the square ain't
stable, but triangles are.

You had to bite your tongue
and put in these diagonals anyway to do this, in
the form on the stairs.

In my mind, that's
what you wanted to do. That's your dream project. You say, well, crap, I got
to put in these stairs. - Yeah.

- Well, if you also got to
put in something diagonal somewhere-- - Uh-huh. - --add it there. - So you're saying the
stairs can be structural?

- Sure. - OK. - If-- and I'll just draw
a simple diagram instead.

But you've built-- you've built
this rectilinear Farnsworth

House steel box. And the engineer says,
it's going to fall down

unless you put in a diagonal. I said, OK, I'll do that. I don't want to-- it was all about
horizontals and verticals.

But if I got to
do that, I got to. - Mm-hmm. - Well, if [INAUDIBLE]
comes along and says, you've got to put in stairs too.

Well, why the hell
not put them--

- Because right now
the stairs themselves-- I mean, not only are they
not helping structurally,

they're not supported
by anything at all. - They don't need to
be supported by much. - Really? - Yeah.

Here's a cool example. And now we're moving from
stairs as structural--

as givers of structural
rigidity to just, what can I do,
structurally, with stairs?

Let's say you've got a
box here and a box here.

You can have stairs attach
here and attach there. You have-- let's add
a third dimension.

Stairs that attach
here and attach there.

Stringers come down and
support the platform. That's supported by
the stringers there.

And that's it, and
there ain't nothing. In section, all you get is-- this is stairs.

Stairs, boom. And there are no columns
and there are no hangars and there's nothing,
like you've got--

like those guys. - Like these? - No, I was thinking
one tier down. No, in between, to the left.

Those guys. - How are they
different from that one? - They're not.

Those come down, and you can
support those on the white box. Those guys don't come down
and sit on the yellow box.

They're just supported-- - Oh. - --by where they come
from and where they go to.

- Ah. - They can be that minimal,
if you want them to-- - Wow. - --structurally speaking. Now if they're doing
that, then they're

not doing much of what we
talked about on the last page. - Mm-hmm. - But it's not all
that difficult.

I like the idea of
the rectilinear planes beside the stairs. - Oh, you like that? - Yeah.

You know-- You want
to catch those. Right now, they're not open
and they're not closed.

- Yeah. - What if you did this? What if you imagine
them as another box.

Just another kind of box. - Ah. - You got two kinds
of boxes here. You've got solid ones. You've got opaque ones and
you got transparent ones.

- That's a good idea. Yeah. - And the opaque ones
come in three colors-- - Yeah. - --and you do stuff in there. And the transparent
ones are stairs.

And the transparent ones
maybe overlap the other ones, as they have to.

Sometimes they dye
into the opaque ones. Sometimes they stand
in front of them. So you've got a box.

Now there's a room,
and here's a room.

And there's a box that overlaps
that guy a little bit and then
comes down and dives into that.
How am I doing? I'm-- - Yeah, I understand. - Yeah, so he's opaque-- - Uh-huh. - --and he's opaque.

- Mm-hmm. - And the stairs are in
these glass boxes in between, and they're all as light
as can possibly be.

The only-- I love
this, the program, the idea of looking at the
north end as the gorge,

as the valley-- - Mm-hmm. - --where you come in and glom
onto the sides of buildings or hang at the top and treat
them just like the landscape.

- Mm-hmm. - The catch is that
we set ourselves

up as completely different than
all the other buildings there. We're not treating
them like colleagues

that we have to get
along with or have any kind of conversation with. We're just treating
them like background. - Mm-hmm.

- Whether you do that or
whether you are more contextual

or how you treat them is
likely to be different, or it's worth considering as
you move on to the next program.

And to this-- - You mean to the
community center? - Yeah. Yeah. In the community
center, if it's really--

well, I can't-- it's hard to
say this without loading it with my own preference, but are you
going to treat the north end

like a quarry,
like a background, like this perch for you to
come in and camp on, or are you

going to go in there as a
citizen and treat the rest of the north end like citizens--

- Right. - --and say, I love you guys. I'm like you guys. I'm with you guys. I'm going to put a building
amongst your buildings,

and then relate to it in all
the ways I have to [INAUDIBLE]..

- When I see myself
in 10 years-- I've always had pets,
and I really, really

enjoy having pets. - Mm-hmm. - And I've grown up
with birds and dogs. - Mm-hmm. - If I'm going to be
living in the city

I probably don't
want to have a dog. Just my personal preference. And so I thought that I
would have birds when I--

10 years from now. And this side that
I was assigned is hanging over the building.

So it lends itself to a
really vertical language. And so what I was
thinking was that I could have this whole
column devoted to the birds

so that they'd be free
to fly around in there. Just the whole thing. And I mean, it's
really tall and narrow,

but it doesn't matter to
them because they can travel. They don't need a
horizontal space.

And then my next thing was
that I put the staircase right next to the
column of birds,

so that I could put these
little perches for myself to go into the room so that
I could be in the room at all

these different places. And some of them would
occur at the landings and be a continuous
space, and some of them

would just be right
off of the stairs. So that when you're
looking at the building, it's just really vertical thing
with just a few perches in it.

And the stairs continue
down the whole way. So that was the start. And then I tried to
echo this language

in the rest of the building. And just to walk you through. This space down here
is the living room,

and then the kitchen's on top. And then lofted
above the kitchen is a dining area with a
little deck on the outside.

And then this is the
bathroom and bedroom. And then you'd open
up to a roof area, so.

This is a south-facing wall. So most of the light's
coming in from this way,
through the bird and the stairs. - You say this is south? - Yeah. Well, north is this way.

This is south facing. I wanted the stairs to be--
ooh, it's coming apart.

Something clear so that
when you look through you still pretty much have the same
elevation that you have here

because I really like
the way it worked.

And so most of my
windows on this thing

are really vertical windows,
going with that vertical theme.

And then what I
started to do was have these little spaces
popping out of the rooms

here and down there. Just going along with
this geometric diagonal.

I mean, that was my
really original sketch. I wanted to play
with this idea of-- - The one all the
way to the left?

- Yeah. - Mm-hmm. - This idea of having these
pretty simple forms interacting

with one another to have
a pretty interesting side. So that's where I am right now.

This was the sketch model. And the progression was that-- I was pretty happy
with this, but I really

didn't like the top. And so I switched the roof
plane so that they matched,

and then I added
this little guy. And then when I had
this top on top of that,

they seemed a little bit ajar,
that this was so regular.

And so then I started taking
out little pieces here and little pieces
here, and then adding

other little vertical numbers. - Mm-hmm. - So that's where
I am right now.

- What do you see
as the materials? - The structure would
be a light steel so that it could be about
a 6 inch square member.

I talked to Dave
about it, and he said that because it's hanging,
it could be a really, really light structure.

And so that,
proportionally, these are actually pretty accurate.

And then the actual materials of
the sidings, I'm not 100% sure. It would be some other light
material, non-traditional.

Maybe like sheet
metal or Plexiglas.

Probably a combination of
things, not just one set. But something really light.

And then I definitely want
to have some opaque pieces so that it breaks up
the thing a little bit.

- Mm-hmm. - So-- - You're developing a
series of little perches

and these guys that are opaque. And I almost want to-- and the translucent of
this whole stairwell

almost separates these
perches from the house. In a way, the different
floors of the house the way

that you've done them,
from the outside, almost look like perches themselves. And I think it would
be really neat to see

that relationship between the
human perches and the bird perches. And the stairs are a very
interesting way to literally--

- So would-- - --cross those - --you think about maybe-- - So I think it might
be interesting to think about the structure
of this and this

in terms of any
horizontal elements that need to be there-- - Uh-huh. - --and make those horizontal
elements work with the use

of the stairwell, access to
these and access to these, which you need. You need access--

- Right. - --to all of those things. And in that way, intermix
some readable structure

that connects all the way
through within this framework. - Yeah.

I mean, some of them would
go through, like this one. This is straight through
into the kitchen level.

- Mm-hmm. So maybe make that-- - The material more solid? - The material, maybe
read-- maybe read that.

And read the uses and the
relationships a little bit more from the outside. And the fact that this is
already so translucent,

I think, will allow us
to see that relationship from the outside
that much better.

If everything is translucent,
